oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Improving Swine Productivity by Treating the Sow
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stanton, H. C.
Brown, L. J.
Siers, D. G.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: animal husbandry
drug treatment program
productivity
livestock performance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The productivity of a swine herd, defined as the quantity of pork marketed per unit cost, can be increased by initiating husbandry practices and/or drug treatment programs which improve the performance of weanling or growing pigs. These drug treatments are predominantly directed toward improving the health of the herd. Modest improvements in rate of body weight gain and feed conversion can be achieved in some herds by treating with antibacterial agents. The exact mechanisms responsible for this effect are not known. Antibacterial agents used to improve livestock performance are occasionally referred to as growth permitting agents since they may improve the animal's health and permit better growth. There are no growth promotant drugs for swine as there are for ruminants, and the opportunity to develop such an agent is attractive.
